title: To Kill a Mockingbird
author: Harper Lee
description: A Pulitzer Prize-winning novel set in the 1930s, exploring racial injustice and moral growth through the eyes of a young girl in Alabama.

author: George Orwell
description: A dystopian novel portraying a totalitarian society where Big Brother watches everyone, and individualism is brutally suppressed.

title: Pride and Prejudice
author: Jane Austen
description: A classic romantic novel revolving around the Bennett sisters, their pursuit of love, and the societal norms of 19th-century England.

title: The Great Gatsby
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
description: Set in the 1920s, this novel depicts the American Dream, wealth, and the tragic love story of Jay Gatsby and Daisy Buchanan.

title: Moby-Dick
author: Herman Melville
description: A tale of Captain Ahab's obsession with hunting down the white whale, Moby-Dick, as it explores themes of obsession and the nature of evil.

title: To the Lighthouse
author: Virginia Woolf
description: A stream-of-consciousness novel that delves into the complex relationships and thoughts of the Ramsay family during their visits to a lighthouse.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
author: J.D. Salinger
description: A coming-of-age novel narrated by Holden Caulfield, a disenchanted teenager struggling with the phoniness of society.

title: Brave New World
author: Aldous Huxley
description: A futuristic novel where humans are genetically engineered and socially conditioned to maintain stability and pleasure in a controlled society.

title: Jane Eyre
author: Charlotte Bronte
description: A bildungsroman following Jane Eyre's journey from her difficult childhood to becoming a governess and her passionate love for Mr. Rochester.

title: The Lord of the Rings
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
description: An epic fantasy trilogy set in Middle-earth, chronicling the perilous quest to destroy the One Ring and defeat the Dark Lord Sauron.

title: The Hobbit
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
description: A prelude to The Lord of the Rings, following Bilbo Baggins as he embarks on an adventure with a group of dwarves to reclaim their homeland.

title: The Odyssey
author: Homer
description: An ancient Greek epic poem that recounts the hero Odysseus' journey home after the Trojan War, encountering mythical creatures and challenges.

title: The Alchemist
author: Paulo Coelho
description: A spiritual allegorical novel about Santiago, an Andalusian shepherd boy, who embarks on a quest to find a hidden treasure.

title: Crime and Punishment
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
description: Set in 19th-century St. Petersburg, this psychological novel explores the mental anguish and moral dilemmas of Rodion Raskolnikov, a poor ex-student.

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
author: Oscar Wilde
description: A novel depicting the moral corruption of Dorian Gray, who remains eternally youthful while a portrait of him ages and reflects his sins.

title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
author: Gabriel Garcia Marquez
description: A multi-generational family saga blending fantasy and reality, exploring the history of the fictional town of Macondo.

title: The Chronicles of Narnia
author: C.S. Lewis
description: A series of fantasy novels following the adventures of children who enter the magical world of Narnia through a wardrobe.

title: Wuthering Heights
author: Emily Bronte
description: A dark tale of love and revenge on the Yorkshire moors, centered around the passionate and tumultuous relationship between Heathcliff and Catherine Earnshaw.

title: The Grapes of Wrath
author: John Steinbeck
description: Set during the Great Depression, this novel tells the story of the Joad family's journey from Oklahoma to California in search of a better life.

title: Anna Karenina
author: Leo Tolstoy
description: A Russian classic exploring themes of love, infidelity, and societal norms through the tragic tale of Anna Karenina and Count Vronsky.

title: Frankenstein
author: Mary Shelley
description: A Gothic novel depicting Dr. Victor Frankenstein's creation of a monster and the moral implications and consequences of his actions.

title: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn
author: Mark Twain
description: A satirical novel following the adventures of Huck Finn and Jim, a runaway slave, as they navigate the Mississippi River and confront racism.

title: The Count of Monte Cristo
author: Alexandre Dumas
description: An adventure novel about Edmond Dantes, who seeks revenge against those who wronged him, set against the backdrop of early 19th-century France.

title: Don Quixote
author: Miguel de Cervantes
description: A comedic and satirical novel that follows the delusional knight Don Quixote and his loyal squire, Sancho Panza, on their quest for chivalry and honor.

title: The Kite Runner
author: Khaled Hosseini
description: Set against the backdrop of Afghanistan's tumultuous history, this novel explores themes of guilt, redemption, and the complex relationship between two friends.

title: Slaughterhouse-Five
author: Kurt Vonnegut
description: A satirical science fiction novel blending time travel and war, exploring the life of Billy Pilgrim, an American soldier in World War II.

title: The Scarlet Letter
author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
description: Set in 17th-century Puritan Boston, this novel follows Hester Prynne, who wears a scarlet letter 'A' as a mark of her adultery, exploring themes of sin, guilt, and redemption.

title: The Iliad
author: Homer
description: An ancient Greek epic poem that depicts the Trojan War and the wrath of Achilles, exploring the themes of honor, glory, and the futility of war.

title: The Brothers Karamazov
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
description: A philosophical novel exploring the lives of three brothers and their father, delving into moral dilemmas, faith, and the nature of human existence.

title: Les Misérables
author: Victor Hugo
description: Set in 19th-century France, this epic novel follows the lives of various characters, including Jean Valjean, against the backdrop of revolution and social injustice.

title: The Divine Comedy
author: Dante Alighieri
description: An epic poem divided into three parts—Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso—depicting the journey of Dante through Hell, Purgatory, and Heaven.

title: The Old Man and the Sea
author: Ernest Hemingway
description: A novella that tells the story of an aging fisherman's struggle with a giant marlin in the Gulf Stream, exploring themes of determination and resilience.

title: The Giver
author: Lois Lowry
description: A dystopian novel set in a future society where emotions and memories are suppressed, following Jonas as he discovers the truth and challenges the system.

title: War and Peace
author: Leo Tolstoy
description: An epic historical novel set in 19th-century Russia, intertwining the lives of various characters against the backdrop of the Napoleonic Wars.

title: The Book Thief
author: Markus Zusak
description: Narrated by Death, this novel follows Liesel Meminger, a young girl in Nazi Germany, as she steals books and finds solace in the power of words.

title: The Stranger
author: Albert Camus
description: An existential novel exploring the absurdity of human existence through the story of Meursault, who faces a moral crisis after committing a murder.

title: The Little Prince
author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
description: A philosophical novella about a young prince who visits various planets and learns important life lessons about friendship, love, and loss.

title: The Hobbit
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
description: A prelude to The Lord of the Rings, following Bilbo Baggins as he embarks on an adventure with a group of dwarves to reclaim their homeland.

title: Gone with the Wind
author: Margaret Mitchell
description: Set during the American Civil War and Reconstruction era, this novel follows Scarlett O'Hara's life, her loves, and the changing Southern society.

title: The Hunger Games
author: Suzanne Collins
description: A dystopian novel set in Panem, a nation divided into districts, where teenagers are forced to participate in a televised fight to the death.

title: A Tale of Two Cities
author: Charles Dickens
description: Set in London and Paris before and during the French Revolution, this historical novel explores the lives of various characters caught in the turmoil.

title: The Handmaid's Tale
author: Margaret Atwood
description: A dystopian novel set in the totalitarian Republic of Gilead, where women are subjugated and Offred narrates her struggle for survival and freedom.

title: The Outsiders
author: S.E. Hinton
description: A coming-of-age novel that follows two rival groups, the Greasers and the Socs, and explores themes of social class, identity, and loyalty.

title: The Hobbit
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
description: A prelude to The Lord of the Rings, following Bilbo Baggins as he embarks on an adventure with a group of dwarves to reclaim their homeland.

title: The Fault in Our Stars
author: John Green
description: A heartwarming and tragic love story between two teenagers with cancer, exploring themes of love, mortality, and the meaning of life.

title: The Secret Life of Bees
author: Sue Monk Kidd
description: Set in the 1960s South, this novel follows a young girl who escapes her troubled home and finds solace and healing in the company of beekeeping sisters.

title: The Book of Lost Things
author: John Connolly
description: A dark fantasy novel following a young boy who discovers a mysterious book that transports him into a world filled with fairy tales and nightmares.

title: The Color Purple
author: Alice Walker
description: Set in the early 20th century, this novel chronicles the life of Celie, an African American woman, as she navigates abuse, racism, and self-discovery.
